Primer$noun$withdef.1$A primer is a short
column2: single-stranded DNA sequence used in the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) technique. In the PCR method
column3: a pair of primers is used to hybridize with the sample DNA and define the region of the DNA that will be amplified. Primers are also referred to as oligonucleotides.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=163

column1: Genetic Drift$noun$withdef.2$Genetic drift is a mechanism of evolution. It refers to random fluctuations in the frequencies of alleles from generation to generation due to chance events. Genetic drift can cause traits to be dominant or disappear from a population. The effects of genetic drift are most pronounced in small populations.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=81

Proband$noun$withdef.3$A proband is an individual being studied or reported on. A proband is usually the first affected individual in a family who brings a genetic disorder to the attention of the medical community.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=164
Repressor$noun$withdef.4$A repressor is a protein that turns off the expression of one or more genes. The repressor protein works by binding to the gene's promoter region
column2: preventing the production of messenger RNA (mRNA).$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=174

column1: Genetic Epidemiology$noun$withdef.5$Genetic epidemiology is a relatively new medical discipline that seeks to understand how genetic factors interact with the environment in the context of disease in populations. Areas of study include the causes of inherited disease and its distribution and control.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=83

complex disease$noun$withdef.6$A complex disease is caused by the interaction of multiple genes and environmental factors. Complex diseases are also called multifactorial. Examples of complex diseases include cancer and heart disease.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=37

Substitution$noun$withdef.7$Substitution is a type of mutation where one base pair is replaced by a different base pair. The term also refers to the replacement of one amino acid in a protein with a different amino acid.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=190
Gene Therapy$noun$withdef.8$Gene therapy is an experimental technique for treating disease by altering the patient's genetic material. Most often
column2: gene therapy works by introducing a healthy copy of a defective gene into the patient's cells.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=77

column1: Pseudogene$noun$withdef.9$A pseudogene is a DNA sequence that resembles a gene but has been mutated into an inactive form over the course of evolution. A pseudogene shares an evolutionary history with a functional gene and can provide insight into their shared ancestry.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=170

antisense$noun$withdef.10$Antisense is the non-coding DNA strand of a gene. A cell uses antisense DNA strand as a template for producing messenger RNA (mRNA) that directs the synthesis of a protein.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=9

Positional Cloning$noun$withdef.11$Positional cloning is a laboratory technique used to locate the position of a disease-associated gene along the chromosome. This approach works even when little or no information is available about the biochemical basis of the disease. Positional cloning is used in conjunction with linkage analysis. It involves the isolation of partially overlapping DNA segments that progress along the chromosome toward a candidate gene.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=162

Gene Pool$noun$withdef.12$A gene pool is the total genetic diversity found within a population or a species. A large gene pool has extensive genetic diversity and is better able to withstand the challenges posed by environmental stresses. Inbreeding contributes to the creation of a small gene pool and makes populations or species more likely to go extinct when faced with some type of stress.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=75
candidate gene$noun$withdef.13$A candidate gene is a gene whose chromosomal location is associated with a particular disease or other phenotype. Because of its location
column2: the gene is suspected of causing the disease or other phenotype.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=21

column1: Mendelian Inheritance$noun$withdef.14$Mendelian inheritance refers to patterns of inheritance that are characteristic of organisms that reproduce sexually. The Austrian monk Gregor Mendel performed thousands of crosses with garden peas at his monastery during the middle of the 19th century. Mendel explained his results by describing two laws of inheritance that introduced the idea of dominant and recessive genes.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=122

Yeast Artificial Chromosome$noun$withdef.15$Yeast artificial chromosome (YAC) is a human-engineered DNA molecule used to clone DNA sequences in yeast cells. YACs are often used in connection with the mapping and sequencing of genomes. Segments of an organism's DNA
column2: up to one million base pairs in length
column3: can be inserted into YACs. The YACs
column4: with their inserted DNA
column5: are then taken up by yeast cells. As the yeast cells grow and divide
column7: which can be isolated and used for DNA mapping and sequencing.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=211

column1: Physical Map$noun$withdef.16$A physical map of a chromosome or a genome that shows the physical locations of genes and other DNA sequences of interest. Physical maps are used to help scientists identify and isolate genes by positional cloning.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=154
bacterial artificial chromosome$noun$withdef.17$A bacterial artificial chromosome (BAC) is an engineered DNA molecule used to clone DNA sequences in bacterial cells (for example
column2: E. coli). BACs are often used in connection with DNA sequencing. Segments of an organism's DNA
column3: ranging from 100
column4: 000 to about 300
column6: can be inserted into BACs. The BACs
column8: are then taken up by bacterial cells. As the bacterial cells grow and divide
column10: which can then be isolated and used in sequencing DNA.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=14

column1: Homologous Recombination$noun$withdef.18$Homologous recombination is a type of genetic recombination that occurs during meiosis (the formation of egg and sperm cells). Paired chromosomes from the male and female parent align so that similar DNA sequences from the paired chromosomes cross over each other. Crossing over results in a shuffling of genetic material and is an important cause of the genetic variation seen among offspring.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=104
Newborn Screening$noun$withdef.19$Newborn screening is testing performed on newborn babies to detect a wide variety of disorders. Typically
column2: testing is performed on a blood sample obtained from a heel prick when the baby is two or three days old. In the United States
column3: newborn screening is mandatory for several different genetic disorders
column4: though the exact set of required tests differs from state to state.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=136

column1: Mitochondrial DNA$noun$withdef.20$Mitochondrial DNA is the small circular chromosome found inside mitochondria. The mitochondria are organelles found in cells that are the sites of energy production. The mitochondria
column2: and thus mitochondrial DNA
column3: are passed from mother to offspring.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=129

column1: First Degree Relative$noun$withdef.21$A first degree relative is a family member who shares about 50 percent of their genes with a particular individual in a family. First degree relatives include parents
column2: offspring
column3: and siblings.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=64

column1: HapMap$noun$withdef.22$HapMap (short for "haplotype map") is the nickname of the International HapMap Project
column2: an international project that seeks to relate variations in human DNA sequences with genes associated with health. A haplotype is a set of DNA variations
column3: or polymorphisms
column4: that tend to be inherited together. A haplotype can refer to a combination of alleles or to a set of single nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) found on the same chromosome.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=98

column1: contig$noun$withdef.23$A contig--from the word "contiguous"--is a series of overlapping DNA sequences used to make a physical map that reconstructs the original DNA sequence of a chromosome or a region of a chromosome. A contig can also refer to one of the DNA sequences used in making such a map.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=39
DNA Replication$noun$withdef.24$DNA replication is the process by which a molecule of DNA is duplicated. When a cell divides
column2: it must first duplicate its genome so that each daughter cell winds up with a complete set of chromosomes.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=50

column1: Gene Expression$noun$withdef.25$Gene expression is the process by which the information encoded in a gene is used to direct the assembly of a protein molecule. The cell reads the sequence of the gene in groups of three bases. Each group of three bases (codon) corresponds to one of 20 different amino acids used to build the protein.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=73

Pharmacogenomics$noun$withdef.26$Pharmacogenomics is a branch of pharmacology concerned with using DNA and amino acid sequence data to inform drug development and testing. An important application of pharmacogenomics is correlating individual genetic variation with drug responses.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=151

Nuclear Membrane$noun$withdef.27$A nuclear membrane is a double membrane that encloses the cell nucleus. It serves to separate the chromosomes from the rest of the cell. The nuclear membrane includes an array of small holes or pores that permit the passage of certain materials
column2: such as nucleic acids and proteins
column3: between the nucleus and cytoplasm.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=139

column1: Polymerase Chain Reaction$noun$withdef.28$Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is a laboratory technique used to amplify DNA sequences. The method involves using short DNA sequences called primers to select the portion of the genome to be amplified. The temperature of the sample is repeatedly raised and lowered to help a DNA replication enzyme copy the target DNA sequence. The technique can produce a billion copies of the target sequence in just a few hours.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=159
Drug Delivery Device$noun$withdef.29$A medical device that contains a clinical drug or drugs.$http://semanticnetwork.nlm.nih.gov/Download/RelationalFiles/SRDEF

Stop Codon$noun$withdef.30$A stop codon is a trinucleotide sequence within a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecule that signals a halt to protein synthesis. The genetic code describes the relationship between the sequence of DNA bases (A
column2: C
column3: G
column4: and T) in a gene and the corresponding protein sequence that it encodes. The cell reads the sequence of the gene in groups of three bases. Of the 64 possible combinations of three bases
column6: while the remaining three combinations are stop codons.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=189

column1: Population Genomics$noun$withdef.31$Population genomics is the application of genomic technologies to understand populations of organisms. In humans
column2: population genomics typically refers to applying technology in the quest to understand how genes contribute to our health and well-being.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=161

column1: Spectral Karyotype$noun$withdef.32$Spectral karyotype (SKY) is a karyotype in which the homologous pairs of chromosomes are manipulated in such a way that they have distinctive colors. The SKY technique makes it easier for scientists to detect chromosomal abnormalities
column2: as compared with a conventional karyotype.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=187

column1: Microarray Technology$noun$withdef.33$Microarray technology is a developing technology used to study the expression of many genes at once. It involves placing thousands of gene sequences in known locations on a glass slide called a gene chip. A sample containing DNA or RNA is placed in contact with the gene chip. Complementary base pairing between the sample and the gene sequences on the chip produces light that is measured. Areas on the chip producing light identify genes that are expressed in the sample.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=125

Missense Mutation$noun$withdef.34$A missense mutation is when the change of a single base pair causes the substitution of a different amino acid in the resulting protein. This amino acid substitution may have no effect
column2: or it may render the protein nonfunctional.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=127

column1: Mouse Model$noun$withdef.35$A mouse model is a laboratory mouse used to study some aspect of human physiology or disease. A variety of different model organisms are used in this regard
column2: but mice are especially useful because they share mammalian features with humans and suffer from many of the same diseases. A large number of mouse models have been created to target specific human diseases using selective breeding and genetic engineering.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=132

column1: Founder Effect$noun$withdef.36$The founder effect is the reduction in genetic variation that results when a small subset of a large population is used to establish a new colony. The new population may be very different from the original population
column2: both in terms of its genotypes and phenotypes. In some cases
column3: the founder effect plays a role in the emergence of new species.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=66

column1: Gene Environment Interaction$noun$withdef.37$Gene environment interaction is an influence on the expression of a trait that results from the interplay between genes and the environment. Some traits are strongly influenced by genes
column2: while other traits are strongly influenced by the environment. Most traits
column3: however
column4: are influenced by one or more genes interacting in complex ways with the environment.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=72

column1: Research Device$noun$withdef.38$A manufactured object used primarily in carrying out scientific research or experimentation.$http://semanticnetwork.nlm.nih.gov/Download/RelationalFiles/SRDEF
Polygenic Trait$noun$withdef.39$A polygenic trait is one whose phenotype is influenced by more than one gene. Traits that display a continuous distribution
column2: such as height or skin color
column3: are polygenic. The inheritance of polygenic traits does not show the phenotypic ratios characteristic of Mendelian inheritance
column4: though each of the genes contributing to the trait is inherited as described by Gregor Mendel. Many polygenic traits are also influenced by the environment and are called multifactorial.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=158

column1: Sickle Cell Disease$noun$withdef.40$Sickle cell disease is a hereditary disease seen most often among people of African ancestry. Caused by mutations in one of the genes that encode the hemoglobin protein
column2: the disease is inherited as an autosomal recessive trait. The mutation causes the red blood cells to take on an unusual sickle shape. Individuals affected by sickle cell disease are chronically anemic and experience significant damage to their heart
column3: lungs
column4: and kidneys.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=184

column1: Fragile X Syndrome$noun$withdef.41$Fragile X syndrome is a hereditary disorder affecting mostly males. Symptoms include mental retardation
column2: distinctive facial features
column3: and poor muscle tone. The syndrome is caused by mutations in a gene on the X chromosome. Since males have a single copy of the X chromosome
column4: they show symptoms if gene on their X chromosome is mutated. Females have a second
column6: copy of the gene on their other X chromosome. Consequently
column7: they are less likely to show symptoms of the syndrome.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=67

column1: Genetic Variation$noun$withdef.42$Genetic variation refers to diversity in gene frequencies. Genetic variation can refer to differences between individuals or to differences between populations. Mutation is the ultimate source of genetic variation
column2: but mechanisms such as sexual reproduction and genetic drift contribute to it as well.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=89

column1: Probe$noun$withdef.43$A probe is a single-stranded sequence of DNA or RNA used to search for its complementary sequence in a sample genome. The probe is placed into contact with the sample under conditions that allow the probe sequence to hybridize with its complementary sequence. The probe is labeled with a radioactive or chemical tag that allows its binding to be visualized. In a similar way
column2: labeled antibodies are used to probe a sample for the presence of a specific protein.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=165

column1: Germ Line$noun$withdef.44$A germ line is the sex cells (eggs and sperm) that are used by sexually reproducing organisms to pass on genes from generation to generation. Egg and sperm cells are called germ cells
column2: in contrast to the other cells of the body that are called somatic cells.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=94

column1: Centimorgan$noun$withdef.45$A centimorgan is a unit used to measure genetic linkage. One centimorgan equals a one percent chance that a marker on a chromosome will become separated from a second marker on the same chromosome due to crossing over in a single generation. It translates to approximately one million base pairs of DNA sequence in the human genome. The centimorgan is named after the American geneticist Thomas Hunt Morgan.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=28
Zebrafish$noun$withdef.46$The zebrafish is a member of the minnow family of fish. The zebrafish is a model organism used to study the development of vertebrates. In this regard
column2: zebrafish are useful because the embryo is transparent
column3: it develops outside of its mother
column4: and its development from eggs to larvae happens in just three days.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=212

column1: Gene Regulation$noun$withdef.47$Gene regulation is the process of turning genes on and off. During early development
column2: cells begin to take on specific functions. Gene regulation ensures that the appropriate genes are expressed at the proper times. Gene regulation can also help an organism respond to its environment. Gene regulation is accomplished by a variety of mechanisms including chemically modifying genes and using regulatory proteins to turn genes on or off.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=76

column1: Open Reading Frame$noun$withdef.48$An open reading frame is a portion of a DNA molecule that
column2: when translated into amino acids
column3: contains no stop codons. The genetic code reads DNA sequences in groups of three base pairs
column4: which means that a double-stranded DNA molecule can read in any of six possible reading frames--three in the forward direction and three in the reverse. A long open reading frame is likely part of a gene.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=146

column1: Holoprosencephaly$noun$withdef.49$Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder that results when the forebrain of the embryo fails to divide and form the right and left halves of the brain. The disorder produces a single-lobed brain structure and severe skull and facial abnormalities. Often the deformities cause babies to die before birth. In mild cases
column2: babies are born with near-normal brain development and facial abnormalities involving cleft lip or cleft palate.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=103

column1: Archaeon$noun$withdef.50$A member of one of the three domains of life
column2: formerly called Archaebacteria under the taxon Bacteria
column3: but now considered separate and distinct. Archaea are characterized by: 1) the presence of characteristic tRNAs and ribosomal RNAs; 2) the absence of peptidoglycan cell walls; 3) the presence of ether-linked lipids built from branched-chain subunits; and 4) their occurrence in unusual habitats. While archaea resemble bacteria in morphology and genomic organization
column4: they resemble eukarya in their method of genomic replication.$http://semanticnetwork.nlm.nih.gov/Download/RelationalFiles/SRDEF

column1: Inherited$noun$withdef.51$An inherited trait is one that is genetically determined. Inherited traits are passed from parent to offspring according to the rules of Mendelian genetics. Most traits are not strictly determined by genes
column2: but rather are influenced by both genes and environment.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=111

column1: Gene Amplification$noun$withdef.52$Gene amplification is an increase in the number of copies of a gene sequence. Cancer cells sometimes produce multiple copies of genes in response to signals from other cells or their environment.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=71

Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism$noun$withdef.53$Restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) is a type of polymorphism that results from variation in the DNA sequence recognized by restriction enzymes. These are bacterial enzymes used by scientists to cut DNA molecules at known locations. RFLPs (pronounced "rif lips") are used as markers on genetic maps. Typically
column2: gel electrophoresis is used to visualize RFLPs.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=176

column1: Professional Society$noun$withdef.54$An organization uniting those who have a common vocation or who are involved with a common field of study.$http://semanticnetwork.nlm.nih.gov/Download/RelationalFiles/SRDEF

Nucleopore$noun$withdef.55$The nucleopore is one of a series of small holes found in the nuclear membrane. The nucleopore serves as a channel used for transporting nucleic acids and proteins into and out of the cell nucleus.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=142
Risk$noun$withdef.56$Risk
column2: in the context of genetics
column3: refers to the probability that an individual will be affected by a particular genetic disorder. Both genes and environment influence risk. An individual's risk may be higher because they inherit genes that cause or increase susceptibility to a disorder. Other individuals may be at higher risk because they live or work in an environment that promotes the development of the disorder.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=179

column1: Codominance$noun$withdef.57$Codominance is a relationship between two versions of a gene. Individuals receive one version of a gene
column2: called an allele
column3: from each parent. If the alleles are different
column4: the dominant allele usually will be expressed
column5: while the effect of the other allele
column9: neither allele is recessive and the phenotypes of both alleles are expressed.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=35

column1: Non-Directiveness$noun$withdef.58$Non-directiveness refers to the nature of the genetic counseling process. According to the principle of non-directiveness
column2: the genetic counselor has the responsibility to provide the client with accurate information about a test or outcome but should remain neutral and not try to influence the decisions made by the client.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=456

column1: carrier screening$noun$withdef.59$Carrier screening is a type of genetic testing performed on people who display no symptoms for a genetic disorder but may be at risk for passing it on to their children. A carrier for a genetic disorder has inherited one normal and one abnormal allele for a gene associated with the disorder. A child must inherit two abnormal alleles in order for symptoms to appear. Prospective parents with a family history of a genetic disorders are candidates for carrier screening.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=24

Frameshift Mutation$noun$withdef.60$A frameshift mutation is a type of mutation involving the insertion or deletion of a nucleotide in which the number of deleted base pairs is not divisible by three. "Divisible by three" is important because the cell reads a gene in groups of three bases. Each group of three bases corresponds to one of 20 different amino acids used to build a protein. If a mutation disrupts this reading frame
column2: then the entire DNA sequence following the mutation will be read incorrectly.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=68

column1: Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act$noun$withdef.61$The Genetic Information Nondiscrimination Act (GINA) is federal legislation that makes it unlawful to discriminate against individuals on the basis of their genetic profiles in regard to health insurance and employment. These protections are intended to encourage Americans to take advantage of genetic testing as part of their medical care. President George W. Bush signed GINA into law on May 22
column2: 2008.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=84

column1: Embryonic Structure$noun$withdef.62$An anatomical structure that exists only before the organism is fully formed; in mammals
column2: for example
column3: a structure that exists only prior to the birth of the organism. This structure may be normal or abnormal.$http://semanticnetwork.nlm.nih.gov/Download/RelationalFiles/SRDEF

column1: Lyonization$noun$withdef.63$Lyonization is commonly known as X-inactivation. In mammals
column2: males receive one copy of the X chromosome while females receive two copies. To prevent female cells from having twice as many gene products from the X chromosomes as males
column3: one copy of the X chromosome in each female cell is inactivated. In placental mammals
column4: the choice of which X chromosome is inactivated is random
column5: whereas in marsupials it is always the paternal copy that is inactivated.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=504

column1: Immunologic Factor$noun$withdef.64$A biologically active substance whose activities affect or play a role in the functioning of the immune system.$http://semanticnetwork.nlm.nih.gov/Download/RelationalFiles/SRDEF

Neoplastic Process$noun$withdef.65$A new and abnormal growth of tissue in which the growth is uncontrolled and progressive. The growths may be malignant or benign.$http://semanticnetwork.nlm.nih.gov/Download/RelationalFiles/SRDEF
Insertion$noun$withdef.66$Insertion is a type of mutation involving the addition of genetic material. An insertion mutation can be small
column2: involving a single extra DNA base pair
column3: or large
column4: involving a piece of a chromosome.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=112

column1: Nonsense Mutation$noun$withdef.67$A nonsense mutation is the substitution of a single base pair that leads to the appearance of a stop codon where previously there was a codon specifying an amino acid. The presence of this premature stop codon results in the production of a shortened
column2: and likely nonfunctional
column3: protein.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=138

column1: Genetic Discrimination$noun$withdef.68$Genetic discrimination is prejudice directed against people who have or may have a genetic disease. Genetic discrimination can involve being denied employment or health insurance. In a healthcare context
column2: it can refer to people being treated based on their genetic status rather than by some more relevant criterion.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=80

column1: Marker$noun$withdef.69$A marker is a DNA sequence with a known physical location on a chromosome. Markers can help link an inherited disease with the responsible genes. DNA segments close to each other on a chromosome tend to be inherited together. Markers are used to track the inheritance of a nearby gene that has not yet been identified but whose approximate location is known. The marker itself may be a part of a gene or may have no known function.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=455
LOD Score$noun$withdef.70$LOD stands for "logarithm of the odds." In genetics
column2: the LOD score is a statistical estimate of whether two genes
column3: or a gene and a disease gene
column4: are likely to be located near each other on a chromosome and are therefore likely to be inherited. A LOD score of 3 or higher is generally understood to mean that two genes are located close to each other on the chromosome. In terms of significance
column5: a LOD score of 3 means the odds are a thousand to one that the two genes are linked

column1: DNA Fingerprinting$noun$withdef.71$DNA fingerprinting is a laboratory technique used to establish a link between biological evidence and a suspect in a criminal investigation. A DNA sample taken from a crime scene is compared with a DNA sample from a suspect. If the two DNA profiles are a match
column2: then the evidence came from that suspect. Conversely
column3: if the two DNA profiles do not match
column4: then the evidence cannot have come from the suspect. DNA fingerprinting is also used to establish paternity.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=49

column1: Knockout$noun$withdef.72$A knockout typically refers to an organism that has been genetically engineered to lack one or more specific genes. Scientists create knockouts (often in mice) so that they can study the impact of the missing genes and learn something about the genes' function.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=454

Phosphate Backbone$noun$withdef.73$A phosphate backbone is the portion of the DNA double helix that provides structural support to the molecule. DNA consists of two strands that wind around each other like a twisted ladder. Each strand has a backbone made of alternating sugar (deoxyribose) and phosphate groups. Attached to each sugar is one of four bases--adenine (A)
column2: cytosine (C)
column3: guanine (G)
column4: or thymine (T). The two strands are held together by bonds between the bases
column5: with adenine forming a base pair with thymine
column6: and cytosine forming a base pair with guanine.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=153

column1: Microbiome$noun$withdef.74$A microbiome is all of the genetic material found within an individual microbe such as a bacterium
column2: fungal cell
column3: or virus.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=502

column1: Personalized Medicine$noun$withdef.75$Personalized medicine is an emerging practice of medicine that uses an individual's genetic profile to guide decisions made in regard to the prevention
column2: diagnosis
column3: and treatment of disease. Knowledge of a patient's genetic profile can help doctors select the proper medication or therapy and administer it using the proper dose or regimen. Personalized medicine is being advanced through data from the Human Genome Project.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=150

column1: Promoter$noun$withdef.76$A promoter is a sequence of DNA needed to turn a gene on or off. The process of transcription is initiated at the promoter. Usually found near the beginning of a gene
column2: the promoter has a binding site for the enzyme used to make a messenger RNA (mRNA) molecule.$http://www.genome.gov/glossary/index.cfm?id=167

column3: gingiva
column4: and the palate

column1: spoon excavator$noun$withdef.78$A curette with hooklike ends used to remove soft carious decay in dentistry.$https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/spoon_excavator
nightguard$noun$withdef.79$A guard worn on the teeth to prevent damage from bruxism during sleep.$https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/nightguard#English
